title: JavaScriptVersions

metadata.description: Learn about JavaScriptVersions with clear explanations and practical examples.

content_sections.title: Details
content_sections.content:
JavaScript was invented by Brendan Eich in 1995, and 
became an ECMA standard  
in 1997.
ECMAScript is the official name of the language.
ECMAScript versions have been abbreviated to ES1, ES2, ES3, ES5, and ES6.
Since 2016, versions are named by year (ECMAScript 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020).
ECMAScript Editions
Ver
Official Name
Description
ES1
ECMAScript 1 (1997)
First edition
ES2
ECMAScript 2 (1998)
Editorial changes
ES3
ECMAScript 3 (1999)
Added regular expressions
Added try/catch
Added switch
Added do-while
ES4
ECMAScript 4
Never released
ES5
ECMAScript 5 (2009)
Read More
Added "strict mode"
Added JSON support
Added String.trim()
Added Array.isArray()
Added Array iteration methods
Allows trailing commas for object literals
ES6
ECMAScript 2015
Read More
Added let and const
Added default parameter values
Added Array.find()
Added Array.findIndex()
ECMAScript 2016
Read More
Added exponential operator (**)
Added Array.includes()
ECMAScript 2017
Read More
Added string padding
Added Object.entries()
Added Object.values()
Added async functions
Added shared memory
Allows trailing commas for function parameters
ECMAScript 2018
Read More
Added rest / spread properties
Added asynchronous iteration
Added Promise.finally()
Additions to RegExp
ECMAScript 2019
Read More
String.trimStart()
String.trimEnd()
Array.flat()
Object.fromEntries
Optional catch binding
ECMAScript 2020
Read More
The Nullish Coalescing Operator (??)
This tutorial covers every version of JavaScript:
The Original JavaScript ES1 ES2 ES3 (1997-1999)
The First Main Revision ES5 (2009)
The Second Revision ES6 (2015)
Yearly Additions (2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020)
Browser Support
ECMAScript 1 - 6 is fully supported in all modern browsers.
Browser Support for ES5 (2009)

Version

Jun 2016
Internet Explorer does not support ECMAScript 2015.

Browser
Version

practice_exercises.description: Create a function that demonstrates the concepts from this tutorial.

quiz.question: What is ECMAScript?
options: the official name of the language
quiz.explanation: The correct definition of ECMAScript is 'the official name of the language'.

quiz.question: What is versions?
options: the official name of the language
quiz.explanation: The correct definition of versions is 'named by year (ECMAScript 2016'.

summary: This tutorial covers JavaScriptVersions concepts and techniques. You'll learn how to use JavaScriptVersions effectively, including key principles, common patterns, and practical examples. By the end of this tutorial, you'll have a solid understanding of JavaScriptVersions and how to apply it in your projects.
